Participantes en el Encuentro Antimperialista compartieron con los vecinos del reparto Barbosa (+Video)

02 Nov 2019, 18:37

Entre música popular bailable, caldosa y vítores de “Viva Cuba” y “Abajo el bloqueo” transcurrió la velada de la noche de este viernes en el reparto Barbosa, al oeste del capitalino municipio de Playa, cuando los participantes en el Encuentro Antimperialista de Solidaridad, por la Democracia y contra el Neoliberalismo recorrieron esa comunidad y compartieron con los vecinos.
Cada presidente de los más de 20 Comités de Defensa de la Revolución (CDR) dio las palabras de bienvenida a los peculiares visitantes y los invitaron a conocer la Cuba que no aparece en las postales de sol y playa.
Guillermo Lamela, secretario del núcleo zonal del Partido Comunista de Cuba, señaló que Barbosa es un reparto humilde e identificado con la Revolución, y recordó a los visitantes que el cubano no comparte lo que le sobra, sino lo que tiene.
El vecino Yosbel Santodomingo declaró que lo ocurrido hoy fue una actividad parecida a la tradicional del 28 de septiembre, día en que se crearon los CDR, y puntualizó que desde horas de la tarde los vecinos, incluyendo niños y ancianos, acondicionaron el lugar y prepararon la comida para los esperados visitantes.
Ileana Medina, del CDR 8, reconoció que la actividad es muy importante porque vincula a Cuba con el mundo y “demuestra que seguimos firmes con los principios de la Revolución, bajo el faro iluminador de Fidel”.
Zamara Blanco, presidenta de ese CDR, expresó que la actividad hoy desarrollada fortalece la unión de las fuerzas progresistas que apuestan por la Revolución, y que constituye una evidencia de que Cuba va por más y que “aquí no se rinde nadie”.

La actividad fue muy conmovedora para las delegaciones foráneas que participan en el evento, quienes quedaron sorprendidos por la unidad del pueblo, la hospitalidad y la alegría de los cubanos.

Mientras, Gerardo Márquez, de Venezuela, aunque ha estado varias veces en la nación caribeña, es la primera ocasión en que visita un barrio. Al respecto, señaló que constituye un honor estar en una Isla que, al igual que su país, resiste con fuerza las agresiones del imperialismo norteamericano.
Peter Burke, de Trinidad y Tobago, confesó que fue una experiencia interesante y que es un fiel defensor de la soberanía de los pueblos.
En tanto, Antonia Vilchez, de Nicaragua, comentó que esta experiencia de los CDR puede ponerse en práctica en su país como forma para consolidar los procesos revolucionarios.
La de hoy no fue una actividad exclusiva para los vecinos de Barbosa. Hubo otros que, tras escuchar los ecos de la iniciativa, recorrieron varios kilómetros y se asomaron con ojos curiosos.
Así lo hizo Pablo Martínez, residente en San Agustín, quien decidió asistir para compartir con amigos de otros países y contarles la realidad que vive Cuba.
La joven Amanda Lamela también entiende la significación de esta fecha, y dijo sentirse emocionada, “pues nunca había estado en una actividad de este tipo”. Para ella, lo más importante del festejo es que los visitantes entendieran la unidad entre las familias y el CDR.

El plato fuerte de la actividad fue un concierto plural por varios artistas nacionales y extranjeros, como Marta Campos, Raúl Torres y Surconciente, que sirvieron de antesala a la presentación del famoso grupo Moncada.



Los vecinos y los participantes al eventos disfrutaron de la música cubana. Fotos: Claudia González Corrales/ACN

text:
‘Hache’: The new Spanish series that seeks to revolutionize Netflix
With the performances of Javier Rey, remembered by his character of Mateo in ‘Velvet’, and Adriana Ugarte, protagonist of ‘The time between seams’, the new production is based on real events of a legendary case of heroin trafficking
02 Nov 2019, 18:37 by Lysalex Hernández A.


Adriana Ugarte and Javier Rey are the protagonists of the series 'Hache', Netflix's new commitment to Spanish productions. Photography: Netflix for La Nación

The sixties began in a convulsive, and somewhat obscure, city of Barcelona, Spain. There, Helena (Adriana Ugarte) makes a living working as a prostitute to be able to support her little daughter, while her husband is serving a sentence in jail for his political ideals.
This will lead her to knock on the door at Albatros, a nightclub in which the wealthiest men in society meet, but in which it also functions as the center of operations of a cartel dedicated to the transfer of heroin.
It will be in this place where the woman will meet Malpica (Javier Rey), who leads the largest drug trafficking band in the city. However, from the first meeting they have both an addictive, but terribly toxic attraction will awaken between them.



The rest of this story is the central plot of the Hache series, whose eight episodes of the first season are already available on Netflix.
Under the creation of Verónica Fernández, the scriptwriter of the successful Velvet series, this thriller arrives on the streaming platform that is based on real-life events, and that will explore drug trafficking in the Barcelona of those years and that even Today is unknown to many.
For the production team of the new Spanish series, this story differs from others in its style due to the fact that it does not seek to focus on the possible victims, but aims to give survivors greater prominence.
This is what Helena represents in the story - who will also be known as Hache - a young woman whom many could consider as a weak woman, but who from the first chapter shows that she is more brave and brave than the people who surround believe.


Javier Rey, who plays Mateo in the series 'Velvet', shows a more dramatic and raw facet with his interpretation as Malpica. Photography: Netflix for La Nación

“I wanted to tell the story from another point of view and that's why I thought about doing it from Hache, thinking what a gangster girl would do if she doesn't want to be the gangster girl, but to be the gangster herself,” Fernández explained in an interview with El Newspaper.
Malpica, the man who thinks he has everything, will soon see how little by little his empire is falling apart, not knowing that his greatest enemy is the one who sleeps by his side.
Female baton
In Hache, the real protagonist will be Helena, who will eventually learn the tricks of the drug trafficking business to become the new leader of the band and, with it, have the power in her hands and restart her life.
"It is a wild animal, without hairs on the tongue and with a moral and personal ethics that will adapt to the circumstances," said actress Adriana Ugarte, who starred in the series The Time Between Seams, at a presentation conference of the new thriller



For her, the most attractive thing about this drama is that it is a woman who bears the baton in this story, which ignores drug trafficking, to give greater participation to the story of the characters that make life survivors .
"Here you will realize that there are no weak or strong characters, but they are simply people who, if they receive violence, respond in the same way," Ugarte told El Periódico.
This is confirmed by the role of Inspector Vinuesa (Eduardo Noriega), who is on the right side of the law and seeks to find those responsible for the drug gang and clean the streets of Barcelona of heroin vendors.
What many do not know is that he also has an addiction: his work, in which he has submerged since his wife died, which has led him to move away from everything that made him feel alive.



Hache is a very good opportunity to know the most sordid and dark facet of a Barcelona of the sixties. Each of the scenes of persecution, sex or violence is justified in the search to remain faithful to the reality of that time. Not surprisingly, one of its protagonists recognizes it.
"The series moves around ambition, need, money, and talks about very primary and dirty emotions that we are ashamed of, but that have a lot to do with human nature," says Ugarte.
Where to see it?
Platform: Netflix
Chapters: Eight
Cast: Adriana Ugarte, Javier Rey and Eduardo Noriega
Screenwriter: Verónica Fernández
